Award.AwardTitle: Antarctic Cloud Physics: Fundamental Observations from Ross Island
Award.AbstractNarration:
Antarctic clouds constitute an important parameter of the surface radiation budget and thus play a significant role in Antarctic climate and climate change. The variability in, and long term trends of, cloud optical and microphysical properties are therefore fundamental in parameterizing the mixed phase (water-snow-ice) coastal Antarctic stratiform clouds experienced around the continent.

Using a spectoradiometer that covers the wavelength range of 350 to 2200nm, the downwelled spectral irradiance at the earth surface (Ross Island) will be used to retrieve the optical depth, thermodynamic phase, liquid water droplet effective radius, and ice-cloud effective particle size of overhead clouds, at hourly intervals and for an austral summer season (Oct-March). Based on the very limited data sets that exist for the maritime Antarctic, expectations are that Ross Island (Lat 78 S) should exhibit clouds with:
a) An abundance of supercooled liquid water, and related mixed-phase cloud processes
b) Cloud nucleation from year round biogenic and oceanic sources, in an otherwise pristine environment
c) Simple cloud geometries of predominantly stratiform cloud decks

Increased understanding of the cloud properties in the region of the main USAP base, McMurdo station is also relevant to operational weather forecasting relevant to aviation. A range of educational and outreach activities are associate with the project, including provision of workshops for high school teachers will be carried out.

Institution.Name: University of California-San Diego Scripps Inst of Oceanography

POR.DRECONTENT:
1. Overview

We made measurements of cloud optical and microphysical properties at Ross Island, Antarctica, using a versatile shortwave spectroradiometer (Panalytical, Inc.) acquired for atmospheric field research by the Scripps Institution of Oceanography (SIO). This instrument measures downwelling spectral irradiance at the Earth surface in the wavelength interval 350-2200 nanometers. This interval contains the visible and much of the near-infrared portions of the electromagnetic spectrum. From these data one can retrieve properties of coastal Antarctic clouds including optical depth, thermodynamic phase, liquid water droplet effective radius, and ice cloud effective particle size. The instrument was installed at Arrival Heights, and measurements were made from 10 October 2012 to 4 February 2013. Data were recorded in one-minute averages, with some gaps for maintenance and data backup. These data are archived at the US Antarctic Program Data Center at Lamont-Doherty Earth Observatory (Lubin, 2017).

2. Interpretation of Spectral Irradiance Data

We demonstrated how shortwave spectral irradiance data could improve understanding of Antarctic cloud microphysics in a set of case studies under contrasting meteorological conditions influencing Ross Island (Scott and Lubin 2014). In our case studies we find that cloud systems arriving at Ross Island after transiting the West Antarctic Ice Sheet (WAIS) and Ross Ice Shelf (RIS) are radiatively dominated by the ice phase. In contrast, moist marine air moving directly onshore from the Ross Sea brings low clouds with a stronger influence of liquid water. Deep cyclonic disturbances over the Ross Sea are seen to be limited in their ability to deliver significant moisture as far south as Ross Island, and in this case most cloud are optically thin.

3. Unique Regime of Antarctic Cloud Microphysics

In Scott and Lubin (2014) we realized that the ice phase is associated with movement of air masses over varying terrain elevation. We then investigated whether the high Antarctic terrain provides a contrast in cloud microphysics with the high Arctic (where most polar atmospheric research has taken place). We compared Ross Island with two well-instrumented Arctic field sites: Barrow Alaska (site of the US Department of Energy Atmospheric Radiation Measurement Program; ARM) and Summit, Greenland (site of the Integrated Characterization of Energy, Clouds, Atmospheric State and Precipitation at Summit, or ICECAPS program). We examined NASA CloudSat and CALIPSO data comparing seasonal variability in microphysical and radiative cloud properties at these three sites, and confirmed that Antarctic orographic lifting provides a strong contrast with the Arctic (Scott and Lubin, 2016).

4. Surface Radiation Budget of the WAIS

With the experience gained from the two above efforts, SIO graduate student researcher Ryan Scott further analyzed NASA remote sensing data and also incorporated broadband radiation measurements from the joint NSF- and DOE-supported ARM West Antarctic Radiation Experiment (AWARE). Here Mr. Scott collaborated with NASA Langley Research Center and Brookhaven National Laboratory (Scott et al. 2017). NASA A-Train cloud observations were combined with surface radiation measurements to quantify the WAIS radiation budget and constrain the three-dimensional occurrence frequency, phase partitioning and surface radiative effect of clouds over West Antarctica. The skill of satellite-modeled radiative fluxes was confirmed through evaluation against measurements from four Antarctic sites (AWARE at WAIS Divide Ice Camp, broadband measurements from Neumayer, Syowa and Concordia stations).

 5. Broader Impacts – Teacher Professional Development

SIO is involved in the UC San Diego STEM Success Initiative (SSI) at the UC San Diego Center for Research on Educational Equity and Assessment Excellence (CREATE), a program to support UCSD involvement in K-14 STEM education. SIO’s contribution to SSI involves providing professional development to prepare science teachers countywide to teach to the recently adopted (in CA) Next Generation Science and Engineering Standards (NGSS).  NGSS differ substantially from earlier science standards in that there are now specific expectations that students demonstrate proficiency in science practices (analyzing and interpreting data; developing and using models, etc.). The program gives teachers a robust approach to working collaboratively with scientists to create lessons that incorporate authentic science research and address the NGSS. In support of this project - and incorporating Antarctic science from this work - we sponsored a workshop series for exemplary middle and/or high school science teachers designed to address this need.

6. Published Work

Scott, R. C., and D. Lubin, 2014: Mixed-phase cloud radiative properties over Ross Island: The influence of various synoptic-scale atmospheric circulation regimes, Journal of Geophysical Research, 119, doi:10.1002/2013JD021132.

Scott, R. C., and D. Lubin, 2016: Unique manifestations of mixed-phase cloud properties over Ross Island and the Ross Ice Shelf, Antarctica. Geophysical Research Letters, 43, 2936-2945, doi:10.1002/2015GL067246.

Scott, R. C., D. Lubin, A. M. Vogelmann, and S. Kato, 2017: West Antarctic Ice Sheet clouds and radiation budget from NASA A-Train satellites. Journal of Climate, 30, 6151-6170, doi:10.1175/JCLI-D-16-0644.1.
